Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: dotnet

Arguments.Name: --version
Arguments.Description: Prints out the version of the .NET SDK used by dotnet commands. Includes the effects of any global.json

Arguments.Name: --info
Arguments.Description: Prints out detailed information about a .NET installation and the machine environment, such as the current operating system, and commit SHA of the .NET version

Arguments.Name: --list-runtimes
Arguments.Description: Prints out a list of the installed .NET runtimes. An x86 version of the SDK lists only x86 runtimes, and an x64 version of the SDK lists only x64 runtimes

Arguments.Name: --list-sdks
Arguments.Description: Prints out a list of the installed .NET SDKs
Prints out a list of available commands

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: --additionalprobingpath
Arguments.Description: Path containing probing policy and assemblies to probe

Arguments.Name: --additional-deps
Arguments.Description: Path to an additional .deps.json file. A deps.json file contains a list of dependencies, compilation dependencies, and version information used to address assembly conflicts. For more information, see Runtime Configuration Files on GitHub

Arguments.Name: -depsfile
Arguments.Description: Path to the deps.json file. A deps.json file is a configuration file that contains information about dependencies necessary to run the application. This file is generated by the .NET SDK

Arguments.Name: --runtimeconfig
Arguments.Description: Path to a runtimeconfig.json file. A runtimeconfig.json file is a configuration file that contains run-time settings

Arguments.Name: --roll-forward
Arguments.Description: Controls how roll forward is applied to the app. The SETTING can be one of the following values. If not specified, Minor is the default

Arguments.Name: --fx-version
Arguments.Description: Version of the .NET runtime to use to run the application

Arguments.Name: new
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new command creates a .NET project or other artifacts based on a template

Arguments.Name: --dry-run
Arguments.Description: Displays a summary of what would happen if the given command were run if it would result in a template creation

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces content to be generated even if it would change existing files. This is required when the template chosen would override existing files in the output directory
Prints out help for the command. It can be invoked for the dotnet new command itself or for any template. For example, dotnet new mvc --help

Arguments.Name: -lang
Arguments.Description: The language of the template to create

Arguments.Name: -n
Arguments.Description: The name for the created output. If no name is specified, the name of the current directory is used

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Location to place the generated output. The default is the current directory

Arguments.Name: --list
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new --list option lists available templates to use with dotnet new

Arguments.Name: --columns
Arguments.Description: Comma-separated list of columns to display in the output

Arguments.Name: --columns-all
Arguments.Description: Displays all columns in the output. Available since .NET Core 5.0.300 SDK

Arguments.Name: --tag
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on template tags. To be selected, a template must have at least one tag that exactly matches the criteria. Available since .NET Core 5.0.300 SDK

Arguments.Name: --search
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new --search option searches for templates supported by dotnet new on NuGet.org

Arguments.Name: --author
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on template author. Partial match is supported

Arguments.Name: --columns
Arguments.Description: Comma-separated list of columns to display in the output

Arguments.Name: --columns-all
Arguments.Description: Displays all columns in the output

Arguments.Name: -lang
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on language supported by the template. The language accepted varies by the template. Not valid for some templates

Arguments.Name: --package
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on NuGet package ID. Partial match is supported

Arguments.Name: --tag
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on template tags. To be selected, a template must have at least one tag that exactly matches the criteria

Arguments.Name: --type
Arguments.Description: Filters templates based on template type. Predefined values are project and item

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET 5.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --nuget-source
Arguments.Description: By default, dotnet new --install uses the hierarchy of NuGet configuration files from the current directory to determine the NuGet source the package can be installed from. If --nuget-source is specified, the source will be added to the list of sources to be checked

Arguments.Name: -u
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new --uninstall command uninstalls a template package at the PATH or NUGET_ID provided

Arguments.Name: --update-check
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new --update-check option checks if there are updates available for the template packs that are currently installed

Arguments.Name: --update-apply
Arguments.Description: The dotnet new --update-apply option checks if there are updates available for the template packages that are currently installed and installs them

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Adds a package reference only when targeting a specific framework

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication

Arguments.Name: -n
Arguments.Description: Adds a package reference without performing a restore preview and compatibility check

Arguments.Name: --package-directory
Arguments.Description: The directory where to restore the packages. The default package restore location is %userprofile%.nugetpackages on Windows and ~/.nuget/packages on macOS and Linux

Arguments.Name: --prerelease
Arguments.Description: Allows prerelease packages to be installed. Available since .NET Core 5 SDK

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: The URI of the NuGet package source to use during the restore operation

Arguments.Name: reference
Arguments.Description: The dotnet add reference command provides a convenient option to add project references to a project. After running the command, the <ProjectReference> elements are added to the project file

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Adds a package reference only when targeting a specific framework

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: The dotnet list package command provides a convenient option to list all NuGet package references for a specific project or a solution. You first need to build the project in order to have the assets needed for this command to process

Arguments.Name: --config
Arguments.Description: The NuGet sources to use when searching for newer packages. Requires the --outdated option

Arguments.Name: --deprecated
Arguments.Description: Displays packages that have been deprecated

Arguments.Name: --framework
Arguments.Description: Displays only the packages applicable for the specified target framework. To specify multiple frameworks, repeat the option multiple times. For example: --framework netcoreapp2.2 --framework netstandard2.0

Arguments.Name: --highest-minor
Arguments.Description: Considers only the packages with a matching major version number when searching for newer packages. Requires the --outdated or --deprecated option

Arguments.Name: --highest-patch
Arguments.Description: Considers only the packages with a matching major and minor version numbers when searching for newer packages. Requires the --outdated or --deprecated option

Arguments.Name: --include-prerelease
Arguments.Description: Considers packages with prerelease versions when searching for newer packages. Requires the --outdated or --deprecated option

Arguments.Name: --include-transitive
Arguments.Description: Lists transitive packages, in addition to the top-level packages. When specifying this option, you get a list of packages that the top-level packages depend on

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --outdated
Arguments.Description: Lists packages that have newer versions available

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: The NuGet sources to use when searching for newer packages. Requires the --outdated or --deprecated option

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: --vulnerable
Arguments.Description: Lists packages that have known vulnerabilities. Cannot be combined with --deprecated or --outdated options

Arguments.Name: reference
Arguments.Description: The dotnet list reference command provides a convenient option to list project references for a given project

Arguments.Name: package
Arguments.Description: The dotnet remove package command provides a convenient option to remove a NuGet package reference from a project

Arguments.Name: reference
Arguments.Description: The dotnet remove reference command provides a convenient option to remove project references from a project

Arguments.Name: -a
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target architecture. This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --arch x86 sets the RID to win-x86. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Compiles for a specific framework. The framework must be defined in the project file

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces all dependencies to be resolved even if the last restore was successful. Specifying this flag is the same as deleting the project.assets.json file

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --no-dependencies
Arguments.Description: Ignores project-to-project (P2P) references and only builds the specified root project

Arguments.Name: --no-incremental
Arguments.Description: Marks the build as unsafe for incremental build. This flag turns off incremental compilation and forces a clean rebuild of the project's dependency graph

Arguments.Name: --no-restore
Arguments.Description: Doesn't execute an implicit restore during build

Arguments.Name: --nologo
Arguments.Description: Doesn't display the startup banner or the copyright message. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --no-self-contained
Arguments.Description: Publishes the application as a framework dependent application. A compatible .NET runtime must be installed on the target machine to run the application

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Directory in which to place the built binaries. If not specified, the default path is ./bin/<configuration>/<framework>/. For projects with multiple target frameworks (via the TargetFrameworks property), you also need to define --framework when you specify this option

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target operating system (OS). This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --os os sets the RID to os-x64. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target runtime. For a list of Runtime Identifiers (RIDs), see the RID catalog. If you use this option, use --self-contained or --no-self-contained also

Arguments.Name: --self-contained
Arguments.Description: Publishes the .NET runtime with the application so the runtime doesn't need to be installed on the target machine. The default is true if a runtime identifier is specified

Arguments.Name: --source
Arguments.Description: The URI of the NuGet package source to use during the restore operation

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: --version-suffix
Arguments.Description: Sets the value of the $(VersionSuffix) property to use when building the project. This only works if the $(Version) property isn't set. Then, $(Version) is set to the $(VersionPrefix) combined with the $(VersionSuffix), separated by a dash

Arguments.Name: build-server
Arguments.Description: Interacts with servers started by a build

Arguments.Name: shutdown
Arguments.Description: Shuts down build servers that are started from dotnet. By default, all servers are shut down

Arguments.Name: --msbuild
Arguments.Description: Shuts down the MSBuild build server

Arguments.Name: --razor
Arguments.Description: Shuts down the Razor build server

Arguments.Name: --vbcscompiler
Arguments.Description: Shuts down the VB/C# compiler build server

Arguments.Name: clean
Arguments.Description: The dotnet clean command cleans the output of the previous build. It's implemented as an MSBuild target, so the project is evaluated when the command is run. Only the outputs created during the build are cleaned. Both intermediate (obj) and final output (bin) folders are cleaned

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project. This option is only required when cleaning if you specified it during build time

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: The framework that was specified at build time. The framework must be defined in the project file. If you specified the framework at build time, you must specify the framework when cleaning

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --nologo
Arguments.Description: Doesn't display the startup banner or the copyright message. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: The directory that contains the build artifacts to clean. Specify the -f|--framework <FRAMEWORK> switch with the output directory switch if you specified the framework when the project was built

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Cleans the output folder of the specified runtime. This is used when a self-contained deployment was created

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: format
Arguments.Description: Dotnet format is a code formatter that applies style preferences to a project or solution. Preferences will be read from an .editorconfig file, if present, otherwise a default set of preferences will be used

Arguments.Name: --diagnostics
Arguments.Description: A space-separated list of diagnostic IDs to use as a filter when fixing code style or third party issues. Default value is whichever IDs are listed in the editorconfig file

Arguments.Name: --severity
Arguments.Description: The minimum severity of diagnostics to fix. Allowed values are info, warn, and error. The default value is warn

Arguments.Name: --no-restore
Arguments.Description: Doesn't execute an implicit restore before formatting. Default is to do implicit restore

Arguments.Name: --verify-no-changes
Arguments.Description: Verifies that no formatting changes would be performed. Terminates with a non zero exit code if any files would have been formatted

Arguments.Name: --include
Arguments.Description: A space-separated list of relative file or folder paths to include in formatting. All files in the solution or project are formatted if empty

Arguments.Name: --exclude
Arguments.Description: A space-separated list of relative file or folder paths to exclude from formatting. The default is none

Arguments.Name: --include-generated
Arguments.Description: Formats files generated by the SDK

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: --binarylog
Arguments.Description: Logs all project or solution load information to a binary log file

Arguments.Name: --report
Arguments.Description: Produces a JSON report in the directory specified by <REPORT_PATH>

Arguments.Name: --format-report-file-json
Arguments.Description: Output migration report file as JSON rather than user messages

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Output migration report to a file in addition to the console

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Skip migrating project references. By default, project references are migrated recursively

Arguments.Name: --skip-backup
Arguments.Description: Skip moving project.json, global.json, and *.xproj to a backup directory after successful migration

Arguments.Name: -t
Arguments.Description: Template csproj file to use for migration. By default, the same template as the one dropped by dotnet new console is used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: The version of the sdk package that's referenced in the migrated app. The default is the version of the SDK in dotnet new

Arguments.Name: -x
Arguments.Description: The path to the xproj file to use. Required when there is more than one xproj in a project directory

Arguments.Name: msbuild
Arguments.Description: The dotnet msbuild command allows access to a fully functional MSBuild

Arguments.Name: delete
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget delete command deletes or unlists a package from the server. For nuget.org, the action is to unlist the package

Arguments.Name: --force-english-output
Arguments.Description: Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -k
Arguments.Description: The API key for the server

Arguments.Name: --no-service-endpoint
Arguments.Description: Doesn't append "api/v2/package" to the source URL. Option available since .NET Core 2.1 SDK

Arguments.Name: --non-interactive
Arguments.Description: Doesn't prompt for user input or confirmations

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Specifies the server URL. Supported URLs for nuget.org include https://www.nuget.org, https://www.nuget.org/api/v3, and https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package. For private feeds, replace the host name (for example, %hostname%/api/v3)

Arguments.Name: locals
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget locals command clears or lists local NuGet resources in the http-request cache, temporary cache, or machine-wide global packages folder

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: The clear option executes a clear operation on the specified cache type. The contents of the cache directories are deleted recursively. The executing user/group must have permission to the files in the cache directories. If not, an error is displayed indicating the files/folders that weren't cleared

Arguments.Name: -l
Arguments.Description: The list option is used to display the location of the specified cache type

Arguments.Name: push
Arguments.Description:
The dotnet nuget push command pushes a package to the server and publishes it. The push command uses server and credential details found in the system's NuGet config file or chain of config files. For more information on config files, see Configuring NuGet Behavior. NuGet's default configuration is obtained by loading %AppData%NuGetNuGet.config (Windows) or $HOME/.local/share (Linux/macOS), then loading any nuget.config or .nuget
uget.config starting from the root of drive and ending in the current directory

Arguments.Name: -d
Arguments.Description: Disables buffering when pushing to an HTTP(S) server to reduce memory usage

Arguments.Name: --force-english-output
Arguments.Description: Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -k
Arguments.Description: The API key for the server

Arguments.Name: --no-service-endpoint
Arguments.Description: Doesn't append "api/v2/package" to the source URL. Option available since .NET Core 2.1 SDK

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Specifies the server URL. NuGet identifies a UNC or local folder source and simply copies the file there instead of pushing it using HTTP

Arguments.Name: --skip-duplicate
Arguments.Description: When pushing multiple packages to an HTTP(S) server, treats any 409 Conflict response as a warning so that the push can continue. Available since .NET Core 3.1 SDK

Arguments.Name: -sk
Arguments.Description: The API key for the symbol server

Arguments.Name: -t
Arguments.Description: Specifies the timeout for pushing to a server in seconds. Defaults to 300 seconds (5 minutes). Specifying 0 applies the default value

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget add source command adds a new package source to your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -p
Arguments.Description: Password to be used when connecting to an authenticated source

Arguments.Name: --store-password-in-clear-text
Arguments.Description: Enables storing portable package source credentials by disabling password encryption

Arguments.Name: -u
Arguments.Description: Username to be used when connecting to an authenticated source

Arguments.Name: --valid-authentication-types
Arguments.Description: Comma-separated list of valid authentication types for this source. Set this to basic if the server advertises NTLM or Negotiate and your credentials must be sent using the Basic mechanism, for instance when using a PAT with on-premises Azure DevOps Server. Other valid values include negotiate, kerberos, ntlm, and digest, but these values are unlikely to be useful

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget disable source command disables an existing source in your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget enable source command enables an existing source in your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --format
Arguments.Description: The format of the list command output: Detailed (the default) and Short

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget list source command lists all existing sources from your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget remove source command removes an existing source from your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: --configFile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget update source command updates an existing source in your NuGet configuration files

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -p
Arguments.Description: Password to be used when connecting to an authenticated source

Arguments.Name: --store-password-in-clear-text
Arguments.Description: Enables storing portable package source credentials by disabling password encryption

Arguments.Name: -u
Arguments.Description: Username to be used when connecting to an authenticated source

Arguments.Name: --valid-authentication-types
Arguments.Description: Comma-separated list of valid authentication types for this source. Set this to basic if the server advertises NTLM or Negotiate and your credentials must be sent using the Basic mechanism, for instance when using a PAT with on-premises Azure DevOps Server. Other valid values include negotiate, kerberos, ntlm, and digest, but these values are unlikely to be useful

Arguments.Name: verify
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget verify command verifies a signed NuGet package

Arguments.Name: --all
Arguments.Description: Specifies that all verifications possible should be performed on the package(s). By default, only signatures are verified

Arguments.Name: --certificate-fingerprint
Arguments.Description: Verify that the signer certificate matches with one of the specified SHA256 fingerprints. This option can be supplied multiple times to provide multiple fingerprints

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. Not supported in every command. See specific command page to determine if this option is available

Arguments.Name: trust
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget trust command manages the trusted signers. By default, NuGet accepts all authors and repositories. These commands allow you to specify only a specific subset of signers whose signatures will be accepted, while rejecting all others

Arguments.Name: list
Arguments.Description: Lists all the trusted signers in the configuration. This option will include all the certificates (with fingerprint and fingerprint algorithm) each signer has. If a certificate has a preceding [U], it means that certificate entry has allowUntrustedRoot set as true

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: sync
Arguments.Description: Deletes the current list of certificates and replaces them with an up-to-date list from the repository

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: remove
Arguments.Description: Removes any trusted signers that match the given name

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: author
Arguments.Description: Adds a trusted signer with the given name, based on the author signature of the package

Arguments.Name: --allow-untrusted-root
Arguments.Description: Specifies if the certificate for the trusted signer should be allowed to chain to an untrusted root. This is not recommended

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: repository
Arguments.Description: Adds a trusted signer with the given name, based on the repository signature or countersignature of a signed package

Arguments.Name: --allow-untrusted-root
Arguments.Description: Specifies if the certificate for the trusted signer should be allowed to chain to an untrusted root. This is not recommended

Arguments.Name: --owners
Arguments.Description: Semicolon-separated list of trusted owners to further restrict the trust of a repository

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: certificate
Arguments.Description: Adds a trusted signer with the given name, based on a certificate fingerprint

Arguments.Name: --algorithm
Arguments.Description: Specifies the hash algorithm used to calculate the certificate fingerprint. Defaults to SHA256. Values supported are SHA256, SHA384 and SHA512

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: source
Arguments.Description: Adds a trusted signer based on a given package source

Arguments.Name: owners
Arguments.Description: Semicolon-separated list of trusted owners to further restrict the trust of a repository

Arguments.Name: --source-url
Arguments.Description: If a source-url is provided, it must be a v3 package source URL (like https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json). Other package source types are not supported

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: sign
Arguments.Description: The dotnet nuget sign command signs all the packages matching the first argument with a certificate. The certificate with the private key can be obtained from a file or from a certificate installed in a certificate store by providing a subject name or a SHA-1 fingerprint

Arguments.Name: --certificate-path
Arguments.Description: Specifies the file path to the certificate to be used in signing the package

Arguments.Name: --certificate-store-name
Arguments.Description: Specifies the name of the X.509 certificate store to use to search for the certificate. Defaults to "My", the X.509 certificate store for personal certificates. This option should be used when specifying the certificate via --certificate-subject-name or --certificate-fingerprint options

Arguments.Name: --certificate-store-location
Arguments.Description: Specifies the name of the X.509 certificate store use to search for the certificate. Defaults to "CurrentUser", the X.509 certificate store used by the current user. This option should be used when specifying the certificate via --certificate-subject-name or --certificate-fingerprint options

Arguments.Name: --certificate-subject-name
Arguments.Description: Specifies the subject name of the certificate used to search a local certificate store for the certificate. The search is a case-insensitive string comparison using the supplied value, which will find all certificates with the subject name containing that string, regardless of other subject values. The certificate store can be specified by --certificate-store-name and --certificate-store-location options

Arguments.Name: --certificate-fingerprint
Arguments.Description: SHA-1 fingerprint of the certificate used to search a local certificate store for the certificate

Arguments.Name: --certificate-password
Arguments.Description: Specifies the certificate password, if needed. If a certificate is password protected but no password is provided, the sign command will fail

Arguments.Name: --hash-algorithm
Arguments.Description: Hash algorithm to be used to sign the package. Defaults to SHA256. Possible values are SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Specifies the directory where the signed package should be saved. If this option is not specified, by default the original package is overwritten by the signed package

Arguments.Name: --overwrite
Arguments.Description: Indicate that the current signature should be overwritten. By default the command will fail if the package already has a signature

Arguments.Name: --timestamp-hash-algorithm
Arguments.Description: Hash algorithm to be used by the RFC 3161 timestamp server. Defaults to SHA256

Arguments.Name: --timestamper
Arguments.Description: URL to an RFC 3161 timestamping server

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: pack
Arguments.Description: The dotnet pack command builds the project and creates NuGet packages. The result of this command is a NuGet package (that is, a .nupkg file)

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces all dependencies to be resolved even if the last restore was successful. Specifying this flag is the same as deleting the project.assets.json file

Arguments.Name: --include-source
Arguments.Description: Includes the debug symbols NuGet packages in addition to the regular NuGet packages in the output directory. The sources files are included in the src folder within the symbols package

Arguments.Name: --include-symbols
Arguments.Description: Includes the debug symbols NuGet packages in addition to the regular NuGet packages in the output directory

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --no-build
Arguments.Description: Doesn't build the project before packing. It also implicitly sets the --no-restore flag

Arguments.Name: --no-dependencies
Arguments.Description: Ignores project-to-project references and only restores the root project

Arguments.Name: --no-restore
Arguments.Description: Doesn't execute an implicit restore when running the command

Arguments.Name: --nologo
Arguments.Description: Doesn't display the startup banner or the copyright message. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Places the built packages in the directory specified

Arguments.Name: --runtime
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target runtime to restore packages for. For a list of Runtime Identifiers (RIDs), see the RID catalog

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Sets the serviceable flag in the package

Arguments.Name: --version-suffix
Arguments.Description: Defines the value for the $(VersionSuffix) MSBuild property in the project

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: publish
Arguments.Description: Dotnet publish compiles the application, reads through its dependencies specified in the project file, and publishes the resulting set of files to a directory

Arguments.Name: -a
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target architecture. This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --arch x86 sets the RID to win-x86. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Publishes the application for the specified target framework. You must specify the target framework in the project file

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces all dependencies to be resolved even if the last restore was successful. Specifying this flag is the same as deleting the project.assets.json file

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --manifest
Arguments.Description: Specifies one or several target manifests to use to trim the set of packages published with the app. The manifest file is part of the output of the dotnet store command. To specify multiple manifests, add a --manifest option for each manifest

Arguments.Name: --no-build
Arguments.Description: Doesn't build the project before publishing. It also implicitly sets the --no-restore flag

Arguments.Name: --no-dependencies
Arguments.Description: Ignores project-to-project references and only restores the root project

Arguments.Name: --nologo
Arguments.Description: Doesn't display the startup banner or the copyright message. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --no-restore
Arguments.Description: Doesn't execute an implicit restore when running the command

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Specifies the path for the output directory

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target operating system (OS). This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --os os sets the RID to os-x64. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: --self-contained
Arguments.Description: Publishes the .NET runtime with your application so the runtime doesn't need to be installed on the target machine. Default is true if a runtime identifier is specified and the project is an executable project (not a library project)

Arguments.Name: --no-self-contained
Arguments.Description: Equivalent to --self-contained false. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Publishes the application for a given runtime. For a list of Runtime Identifiers (RIDs), see the RID catalog

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: --version-suffix
Arguments.Description: Defines the version suffix to replace the asterisk (*) in the version field of the project file

Arguments.Name: restore
Arguments.Description: The dotnet restore command uses NuGet to restore dependencies as well as project-specific tools that are specified in the project file

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --disable-parallel
Arguments.Description: Disables restoring multiple projects in parallel

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces all dependencies to be resolved even if the last restore was successful. Specifying this flag is the same as deleting the project.assets.json file

Arguments.Name: -force-evaluate
Arguments.Description: Forces restore to reevaluate all dependencies even if a lock file already exists

Arguments.Name: --ignore-failed-sources
Arguments.Description: Only warn about failed sources if there are packages meeting the version requirement

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication

Arguments.Name: --lock-file-path
Arguments.Description: Output location where project lock file is written. By default, this is PROJECT_ROOTpackages.lock.json

Arguments.Name: --locked-mode
Arguments.Description: Don't allow updating project lock file

Arguments.Name: --no-cache
Arguments.Description: Specifies to not cache HTTP requests

Arguments.Name: --no-dependencies
Arguments.Description: When restoring a project with project-to-project (P2P) references, restores the root project and not the references

Arguments.Name: --packages
Arguments.Description: Specifies the directory for restored packages

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Specifies a runtime for the package restore. This is used to restore packages for runtimes not explicitly listed in the <RuntimeIdentifiers> tag in the .csproj file

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Specifies the URI of the NuGet package source to use during the restore operation. This setting overrides all of the sources specified in the nuget.config files. Multiple sources can be provided by specifying this option multiple times

Arguments.Name: --use-lock-file
Arguments.Description: Enables project lock file to be generated and used with restore

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: run
Arguments.Description: The dotnet run command provides a convenient option to run your application from the source code with one command. It's useful for fast iterative development from the command line. The command depends on the dotnet build command to build the code. Any requirements for the build, such as that the project must be restored first, apply to dotnet run as well
Delimits arguments to dotnet run from arguments for the application being run. All arguments after this delimiter are passed to the application run

Arguments.Name: -a
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target architecture. This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --arch x86 sets the RID to win-x86. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Builds and runs the app using the specified framework. The framework must be specified in the project file

Arguments.Name: --force
Arguments.Description: Forces all dependencies to be resolved even if the last restore was successful. Specifying this flag is the same as deleting the project.assets.json file

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: --launch-profile
Arguments.Description: The name of the launch profile (if any) to use when launching the application. Launch profiles are defined in the launchSettings.json file and are typically called Development, Staging, and Production

Arguments.Name: --no-build
Arguments.Description: Doesn't build the project before running. It also implicit sets the --no-restore flag

Arguments.Name: --no-dependencies
Arguments.Description: When restoring a project with project-to-project (P2P) references, restores the root project and not the references

Arguments.Name: --no-launch-profile
Arguments.Description: Doesn't try to use launchSettings.json to configure the application

Arguments.Name: --no-restore
Arguments.Description: Doesn't execute an implicit restore when running the command

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target operating system (OS). This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --os os sets the RID to os-x64. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: --project
Arguments.Description: Specifies the path of the project file to run (folder name or full path). If not specified, it defaults to the current directory. The -p abbreviation for --project is deprecated starting in .NET 6 Preview SDK

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target runtime to restore packages for. For a list of Runtime Identifiers (RIDs), see the RID catalog. -r short option available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: list
Arguments.Description: Lists all projects in a solution file

Arguments.Name: add
Arguments.Description: Adds one or more projects to the solution file

Arguments.Name: --in-root
Arguments.Description: Places the projects in the root of the solution, rather than creating a solution folder. Can't be used with -s|--solution-folder. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: The destination solution folder path to add the projects to. Can't be used with --in-root. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: remove
Arguments.Description: Removes a project or multiple projects from the solution file

Arguments.Name: store
Arguments.Description: Dotnet store stores the specified assemblies in the runtime package store. By default, assemblies are optimized for the target runtime and framework. For more information, see the runtime package store topic

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target framework. The target framework has to be specified in the project file

Arguments.Name: -m
Arguments.Description: The package store manifest file is an XML file that contains the list of packages to store. The format of the manifest file is compatible with the SDK-style project format. So, a project file that references the desired packages can be used with the -m|--manifest option to store assemblies in the runtime package store

Arguments.Name: --framework-version
Arguments.Description: Specifies the .NET SDK version. This option enables you to select a specific framework version beyond the framework specified by the -f|--framework option

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Specifies the path to the runtime package store. If not specified, it defaults to the store subdirectory of the user profile .NET installation directory

Arguments.Name: --skip-symbols
Arguments.Description: Skips symbol generation. Currently, you can only generate symbols on Windows and Linux

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: -w
Arguments.Description: The working directory used by the command. If not specified, it uses the obj subdirectory of the current directory

Arguments.Name: test
Arguments.Description: The dotnet test command is used to execute unit tests in a given solution. The dotnet test command builds the solution and runs a test host application for each test project in the solution. The test host executes tests in the given project using a test framework, for example: MSTest, NUnit, or xUnit, and reports the success or failure of each test. If all tests are successful, the test runner returns 0 as an exit code; otherwise if any test fails, it returns 1

Arguments.Name: -a
Arguments.Description: Path to a directory to be searched for additional test adapters. Only .dll files with suffix .TestAdapter.dll are inspected. If not specified, the directory of the test .dll is searched

Arguments.Name: --arch
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target architecture. This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --arch x86 sets the RID to win-x86. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: --blame
Arguments.Description: Runs the tests in blame mode. This option is helpful in isolating problematic tests that cause the test host to crash. When a crash is detected, it creates a sequence file in TestResults/<Guid>/<Guid>_Sequence.xml that captures the order of tests that were run before the crash

Arguments.Name: --blame-crash
Arguments.Description: Runs the tests in blame mode and collects a crash dump when the test host exits unexpectedly. This option depends on the version of .NET used, the type of error, and the operating system

Arguments.Name: --blame-crash-dump-type
Arguments.Description: The type of crash dump to be collected. Implies --blame-crash

Arguments.Name: --blame-crash-collect-always
Arguments.Description: Collects a crash dump on expected as well as unexpected test host exit

Arguments.Name: --blame-hang
Arguments.Description: Run the tests in blame mode and collects a hang dump when a test exceeds the given timeout

Arguments.Name: --blame-hang-timeout
Arguments.Description: Per-test timeout, after which a hang dump is triggered and the test host process and all of its child processes are dumped and terminated

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Defines the build configuration. The default for most projects is Debug, but you can override the build configuration settings in your project

Arguments.Name: --collect
Arguments.Description: Enables data collector for the test run

Arguments.Name: -d
Arguments.Description: Enables diagnostic mode for the test platform and writes diagnostic messages to the specified file and to files next to it. The process that is logging the messages determines which files are created, such as *.host_<date>.txt for test host log, and *.datacollector_<date>.txt for data collector log

Arguments.Name: -f
Arguments.Description: Forces the use of dotnet or .NET Framework test host for the test binaries. This option only determines which type of host to use. The actual framework version to be used is determined by the runtimeconfig.json of the test project. When not specified, the TargetFramework assembly attribute is used to determine the type of host. When that attribute is stripped from the .dll, the .NET Framework host is used

Arguments.Name: --filter
Arguments.Description: Filters out tests in the current project using the given expression. For more information, see the Filter option details section. For more information and examples on how to use selective unit test filtering, see Running selective unit tests

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -l
Arguments.Description: Specifies a logger for test results. Unlike MSBuild, dotnet test doesn't accept abbreviations: instead of -l "console;v=d" use -l "console;verbosity=detailed". Specify the parameter multiple times to enable multiple loggers

Arguments.Name: --no-build
Arguments.Description: Doesn't build the test project before running it. It also implicitly sets the - --no-restore flag

Arguments.Name: --nologo
Arguments.Description: Run tests without displaying the Microsoft TestPlatform banner. Available since .NET Core 3.0 SDK

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Directory in which to find the binaries to run. If not specified, the default path is ./bin/<configuration>/<framework>/. For projects with multiple target frameworks (via the TargetFrameworks property), you also need to define --framework when you specify this option. dotnet test always runs tests from the output directory. You can use AppDomain.BaseDirectory to consume test assets in the output directory

Arguments.Name: --os
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target operating system (OS). This is a shorthand syntax for setting the Runtime Identifier (RID), where the provided value is combined with the default RID. For example, on a win-x64 machine, specifying --os os sets the RID to os-x64. If you use this option, don't use the -r|--runtime option. Available since .NET 6 Preview 7

Arguments.Name: -r
Arguments.Description: The directory where the test results are going to be placed. If the specified directory doesn't exist, it's created. The default is TestResults in the directory that contains the project file

Arguments.Name: --runtime
Arguments.Description: The target runtime to test for

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: The .runsettings file to use for running the tests. The TargetPlatform element (x86|x64) has no effect for dotnet test. To run tests that target x86, install the x86 version of .NET Core. The bitness of the dotnet.exe that is on the path is what will be used for running tests

Arguments.Name: -t
Arguments.Description: List the discovered tests instead of running the tests

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal. For more information, see LoggerVerbosity

Arguments.Name: tool
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool install command provides a way for you to install .NET tools on your machine

Arguments.Name: --add-source
Arguments.Description: Adds an additional NuGet package source to use during installation. Feeds are accessed in parallel, not sequentially in some order of precedence. If the same package and version is in multiple feeds, the fastest feed wins

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --disable-parallel
Arguments.Description: Prevent restoring multiple projects in parallel

Arguments.Name: --framework
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target framework to install the tool for. By default, the .NET SDK tries to choose the most appropriate target framework

Arguments.Name: -g
Arguments.Description: Specifies that the installation is user wide. Can't be combined with the --tool-path option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path specifies a local tool installation

Arguments.Name: --ignore-failed-sources
Arguments.Description: Treat package source failures as warnings

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication

Arguments.Name: --local
Arguments.Description: Update the tool and the local tool manifest. Can't be combined with the --global option or the --tool-path option

Arguments.Name: --no-cache
Arguments.Description: Do not cache packages and HTTP requests

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: --version
Arguments.Description: The version of the tool to install. By default, the latest stable package version is installed. Use this option to install preview or older versions of the tool

Arguments.Name: list
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool list command provides a way for you to list all .NET global, tool-path, or local tools installed on your machine. The command lists the package name, version installed, and the tool command

Arguments.Name: -g
Arguments.Description: Lists user-wide global tools. Can't be combined with the --tool-path option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path lists local tools

Arguments.Name: --local
Arguments.Description: Lists local tools for the current directory. Can't be combined with the --global or --tool-path options. Omitting both --global and --tool-path lists local tools even if --local is not specified

Arguments.Name: --tool-path
Arguments.Description: Specifies a custom location where to find global tools. PATH can be absolute or relative. Can't be combined with the --global option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path lists local tools

Arguments.Name: restore
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool restore command finds the tool manifest file that is in scope for the current directory and installs the tools that are listed in it. For information about manifest files, see Install a local tool and Invoke a local tool

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --add-source
Arguments.Description: Adds an additional NuGet package source to use during installation. Feeds are accessed in parallel, not sequentially in some order of precedence. If the same package and version is in multiple feeds, the fastest feed wins

Arguments.Name: --ignore-failed-sources
Arguments.Description: Treat package source failures as warnings

Arguments.Name: --no-cache
Arguments.Description: Do not cache packages and HTTP requests

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: run
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool run command searches tool manifest files that are in scope for the current directory. When it finds a reference to the specified tool, it runs the tool

Arguments.Name: search
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool search command provides a way for you to search NuGet for tools that can be used as .NET global, tool-path, or local tools. The command searches the tool names and metadata such as titles, descriptions, and tags

Arguments.Name: --detail
Arguments.Description: Shows detailed results from the query

Arguments.Name: --skip
Arguments.Description: Specifies the number of query results to skip. Used for pagination

Arguments.Name: --take
Arguments.Description: Specifies the number of query results to show. Used for pagination

Arguments.Name: uninstall
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool uninstall command provides a way for you to uninstall .NET tools from your machine

Arguments.Name: -g
Arguments.Description: Specifies that the tool to be removed is from a user-wide installation. Can't be combined with the --tool-path option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path specifies that the tool to be removed is a local tool

Arguments.Name: --tool-path
Arguments.Description: Specifies the location where to uninstall the tool. PATH can be absolute or relative. Can't be combined with the --global option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path specifies that the tool to be removed is a local tool

Arguments.Name: update
Arguments.Description: The dotnet tool update command provides a way for you to update .NET tools on your machine to the latest stable version of the package

Arguments.Name: --add-source
Arguments.Description: Adds an additional NuGet package source to use during installation. Feeds are accessed in parallel, not sequentially in some order of precedence. If the same package and version is in multiple feeds, the fastest feed wins

Arguments.Name: --configfile
Arguments.Description: The NuGet configuration file (nuget.config) to use. If specified, only the settings from this file will be used. If not specified, the hierarchy of configuration files from the current directory will be used

Arguments.Name: --disable-parallel
Arguments.Description: Prevent restoring multiple projects in parallel

Arguments.Name: --framework
Arguments.Description: Specifies the target framework to install the tool for. By default, the .NET SDK tries to choose the most appropriate target framework

Arguments.Name: -g
Arguments.Description: Specifies that the installation is user wide. Can't be combined with the --tool-path option. Omitting both --global and --tool-path specifies a local tool installation

Arguments.Name: --ignore-failed-sources
Arguments.Description: Treat package source failures as warnings

Arguments.Name: --interactive
Arguments.Description: Allows the command to stop and wait for user input or action. For example, to complete authentication

Arguments.Name: --local
Arguments.Description: Update the tool and the local tool manifest. Can't be combined with the --global option or the --tool-path option

Arguments.Name: --no-cache
Arguments.Description: Do not cache packages and HTTP requests

Arguments.Name: -v
Arguments.Description: Sets the verbosity level of the command. Allowed values are q[uiet], m[inimal], n[ormal], d[etailed], and diag[nostic]. The default is minimal

Arguments.Name: --version
Arguments.Description: The version of the tool to install. By default, the latest stable package version is installed. Use this option to install preview or older versions of the tool
